perturbation.original_text: 9.1 If you are unable to attend at work by reason of sickness or injury or any unauthorised reason you must inform the Company as soon as possible on the first day of absence (and in any event not later than 11.00 am on the first day of absence) and, in the case of absence of uncertain duration, you must keep the Company regularly informed of your continued absence and your likely date of return. You are expected to observe this rule very strictly since failure to do so will entitle the Company to stop payment in respect of each day you fail to notify the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.1 If you are unable to attend at work by reason of sickness or injury or any unauthorised reason you must inform the Company as soon as possible on the first day of absence (and in any event not later than 4.00 pm on the first day of absence) and, in the case of absence of uncertain duration, you must keep the Company regularly informed of your continued absence and your likely date of return. You are expected to observe this rule very strictly since failure to do so will entitle the Company to stop payment in respect of each day you fail to notify the Company.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause requires notification of absence due to illness or injury no later than 11:00 am on the first day of absence. The modified clause extends this deadline to 4:00 pm. This introduces a contradiction, as employment laws often specify strict notification timelines, and altering this deadline could lead to disputes regarding compliance and potential penalties for late notification under company policy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Employment Rights Act 1996 (potential breach if company policy predicated on this notification is used to unfairly penalise the employee).

perturbation.original_text: 11.7 If your employment is terminated on account of your death or by the Company without Cause (being for any reason not covered by paragraph 11.3), or you terminate your employment for Good Reason (as provided in paragraph 11.4), in either case outside of the Change in Control Period, then the Company shall pay you the Accrued Benefits. In addition, subject to (i) your (or your authorised representative or estate signing, if the termination is due to your death) signing a settlement agreement and a separation agreement and release (together the "Settlement Agreements") in a form and manner satisfactory to the Company, which shall include, without limitation, a general release of claims against the Company and all related persons and entities, a reaffirmation of all of your continuing obligations to the Company, including those set forth in paragraphs 13 - 15, and (in the case of the separation agreement and release) and a seven (7) business day revocation period; and (ii) the separation agreement and release becoming irrevocable, all within 60 days after the Termination Date (or such shorter period as set forth in the Settlement Agreements), the Company shall: (A) pay you (or your authorised representative or estate if the termination is due to your death) an amount equal to nine (9) months of your salary as of the Termination Date (which payment shall not be reduced by either the value of any salary paid to you during your notice period or by any payment in lieu of notice made pursuant to paragraph 11.2); and (B) pay you (or your authorised representative or estate if the termination is due to your death) an amount equal to the cost to the Company of providing you with the contractual benefits under paragraph 5 for nine (9) months or, at the Company's option, continue to provide you with such benefits for nine (9) months.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.7 If your employment is terminated on account of your death or by the Company without Cause (being for any reason not covered by paragraph 11.3), or you terminate your employment for Good Reason (as provided in paragraph 11.4), in either case outside of the Change in Control Period, then the Company shall pay you the Accrued Benefits. In addition, subject to (i) your (or your authorised representative or estate signing, if the termination is due to your death) signing a settlement agreement and a separation agreement and release (together the "Settlement Agreements") in a form and manner satisfactory to the Company, which shall include, without limitation, a general release of claims against the Company and all related persons and entities, a reaffirmation of all of your continuing obligations to the Company, including those set forth in paragraphs 13 - 15, and (in the case of the separation agreement and release) and a three (3) business day revocation period; and (ii) the separation agreement and release becoming irrevocable, all within 60 days after the Termination Date (or such shorter period as set forth in the Settlement Agreements), the Company shall: (A) pay you (or your authorised representative or estate if the termination is due to your death) an amount equal to nine (9) months of your salary as of the Termination Date (which payment shall not be reduced by either the value of any salary paid to you during your notice period or by any payment in lieu of notice made pursuant to paragraph 11.2); and (B) pay you (or your authorised representative or estate if the termination is due to your death) an amount equal to the cost to the Company of providing you with the contractual benefits under paragraph 5 for nine (9) months or, at the Company's option, continue to provide you with such benefits for nine (9) months.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a seven (7) business day revocation period for the separation agreement and release. The modified text reduces this to three (3) business days. This creates a potential legal issue because, depending on jurisdiction and applicable laws regarding severance agreements and release of claims, a three-day revocation period might be considered insufficient for the employee to make a fully informed decision, making the release potentially unenforceable. Many jurisdictions in the United States, by comparison, afford the employee a minimum of seven days' consideration period for a severance agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Varies by jurisdiction (e.g., Older Workers Benefit Protection Act (OWBPA) in the US requires 7 days for age discrimination claims).

perturbation.original_text: 8.3 The holiday year runs from January to December. With the agreement of the CEO, you may carry forward up to 5 days of untaken holiday into the next holiday year. Any carried over holiday must be taken by the end of March of the following calendar year or will be forfeited and no payment will be made in respect of any days so forfeited. You will not generally be permitted to take more than 10 days holiday at any one time.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.3 The holiday year runs from January to December. With the agreement of the CEO, you may carry forward up to 5 days of untaken holiday into the next holiday year. Any carried over holiday must be taken by the end of January of the following calendar year or will be forfeited and no payment will be made in respect of any days so forfeited. You will not generally be permitted to take more than 10 days holiday at any one time.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause allows carried-over holiday to be taken until the end of March. The modified clause shortens this period to the end of January. This could conflict with UK Working Time Regulations, which mandate that employers must allow workers to take their statutory holiday entitlement, and unreasonably restricting the carry-over period could be seen as hindering this right. The change introduces a stricter timeline for using the accrued leave, potentially disadvantaging the employee. In many cases leave entitlement has to be at least 28 days, and any forfeiture would have to be reasonable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Working Time Regulations 1998 (potential violation of the right to take statutory holiday entitlement).
